posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I am a fucking fat piggy rat and I have very bad anxiety. I have tried forming habits in the past but I have failed twice till now, but considering habit formation is the only thing that worked for me I am ready to give it another try
You can start from anywhere really, evaluating where you stand and how strong your will is but be aware that your number 1 goal is consistency, not perfection. You have to be mediocre before you can be great.

I have started journaling and reading 20 minutes before bed. Even though I am a lazy fuck throughout the day I have something to do before going to sleep. I am gonna integrate morning walks as soon as I fix my sleeping schedule.
As I said, look where you stand and go from there. Your first isnt to push yourself, you'll scare yourself and end up in a ditch again. Just see the bare minimum you can do and do it everyday till you are comfortable with pushing it up a notch
Then again, I am a depressed fat fuck who is scared of people and no goals or purpose, you might actually be in a better position than compared to me considering I cant even push myself to take daily showers.
Hope I helped good luck anon I hope you make it

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28160866
>Heterosexuals,
>What do you talk about on a date?
Curious as to why you think gay or bi people would have different conversational topics...?

The answer is always going to be "pretty much anything". Dating is basically just hanging out with a person because you like them and it's fun.

If you're stuck for a topic, then talking about your hobbies can be a good choice - sounding passionate about something is attractive. Take an interest in the other person, but don't make it sound like an interrogation. Talk enough about yourself that you sound open and honest, but not so much that you sound self-important.

On a first date it's probably a good idea not to talk about politics, or any topic that people are likely to get upset about; at that point you just want the other person to associate you with having fun, so keep it reasonably light. Further down the line, just talk about whatever you want to talk about.

>thanks yeah thats actually was my old goal bc i really didnt think i would even get as far as i am this young and with my history... i just always hear they make worse money even comparable to working in a restaurant.

You are correct that EMTs don't get paid well, but the point is to gain some experience and expertise and not do that as a career. Most entry level jobs have little room for advancement unless the end goal is being an Asst. Manager at McDonalds or KFC. Treat EMT like a stepping stone and to determine if health care is a serious path for you. With a year or so of experience Advanced EMT or Paramedic are options as a first responder. If you want rather high status while being a working stiff then flight medic punches that ticket. If you want to make more money then that knowledge will make nursing school or furthering education toward PA programs vastly easier.

I was an EMT when I was in my teens and eventually went to nursing school. EMT paid for shit, but first year out of nursing school I made over $82k with a fair amount of overtime. That EMT experience paid dividends and it still does now.

Sorry to hear, bro. See, my parents never abused me blatantly either. Childhood trauma can be inflicted without physical/sexual/verbal abuse; and parents can be dysfunctional without intending to hurt their children. There are 'big' T's (traumas), and little t's' - (small traumas). And all of them are embedded in each of us as people if we grew up around them. It isn't obvious to ourselves, but it is indeed buried in our subconscious - see, when we were kids we developed a sense of 'self', yeah? So the child brain needs a 'blueprint' to mold its 'self' around. Those would be your parents.

Depending on how your parents routinely behaved it can and will affect your relationships. There is always a 1:1 direct parallel. How your relationship dynamics played out with your parents will play out with your future partners. It sounds crazy, but it's also simple. It's also the truth.

Myself for example:
>Parents argue a lot, clearly not in 'love', but stick together
>Parents don't abuse me
>Parents occasionally give me affection
>Don't believe them deep down, I just saw them not love each other, so their 'love' isn't secure

>Notice how every time there's 'peace' there is 'chaos' right after
>Grow older, find girlfriend
>Find myself codependently attached
>Feeling like I ought to 'work' at being loved
>Get walked over, but stay because if I appease there is peace, affection

>Rinse and repeat

No one is good at this, and there is probably very little that you can do. The main thing is just to be with her as much as you can, while being careful to tell her to just let you know when she wants to be alone. Don't talk too much, just keep her company and listen if she wants to talk. Bring something to read, quietly help out, be in and out of the house. One thing to keep in mind is that dealing with this sort of thing can be a lot of work, and for someone who is already exhausted by their grief. Without jumping the gun about it, take care of household things and errands for her if you can. Ask if she'd like you to handle phone calls or texts as she will be inundated with those. See if she would like you to go through his things or store his papers and so forth somewhere for later.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Have you previously had a relationship with your friend? Has anything physical ever happened? Do you know if she has romantic feelings for you?

I was in basically an identical situation and I chose my dull girlfriend. That was over a decade ago now, and we are married and have two incredible kids. Our marriage isn't perfect but it is pretty good. Sex isn't great but it isn't awful either. I think about the fun best friend a lot to be honest. In fact, this is probably the only thing i'd never tell my wife. I wonder what might have been. I think my 20s would have been a lot more fun. I think I would have had much better sex than I have ever had. But I wouldn't have the home I have and she wouldn't be as good a mother as my wife is. My best friend is a fantasy. The issue is, I argue with my wife sometimes and allow the fantasy to seem more appealing, then I resent my wife for it. This is folly. It is bullshit. Girls like your friend are fun and dramatic, but they are not permanent. Can you imagine yourself with her picking out paint for a living room? Going through brochures for local pre-schools? Buying a car? Any of the dull shit that makes up such a huge part of life? I picked my wife because we are compatible in the quiet and dull moments, and although I occassionally jerk off to memories of my friend I know deep down that all we would have had was quick fun. Probably travelling and sex and then an awful realisation that we don't click as a couple the second we stop to catch our breath.
My advice is this: figure out if you and your friend can just be boring adults together sometimes. If not, it is hopeless.
Also, make sure that if you pick your current girlfriend you do not resent her for the fun you missed out on. You are trading that fun for compassion, stability, and a good mother for your kids. If you think you might forget this then don't subject her to life with a partner that resents her.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Yeah man, heavy trauma doesn't go away or need an 'excuse'. Have a fucked up childhood? Guess what, that'll impact upon your whole life. In all honesty, any significant trauma will impact you until you decide you are ready to process it. Processing it is messy and not automatically the best thing to do at any time. Dealing with it doesn't mean it goes away, it means you develop resistance and healthier coping strategies. OP you are basically say "so what you had it rough, time to suck it up and move on, man up, toughen up".

I'm not giving your Dad a pass either. Trauma is really fucking annoying especially when you are forced to rely upon somebody who isn't ready to deal with it and the negative impact of it upon them spills out onto you and those you know and love.

As cold as it sounds a lot of the time the only responsible reaction towards somebody with a lot of trauma is empathy and distance. If you can't cope with their bullshit and the relationship is thus unhealthy and they aren't ready to change then all you can do (authentically) is move on. No point in remaining in the zone, raging against something outside of your control.

Usually the more loss the trauma creates and the more it holds them back the more likely they are to become ready to prioritise dealing with their bullshit. Also ... while you might look at this and say ... whatever, I could just man up and power through this shit no problem, they are being weak and making excuses (and sometimes you might be a little bit right) you've not experienced their experience you've not lived this shit and you've no way of knowing how you'd react or how you would deal with it when similarly tested, be thankful that you haven't because it can get complex. Some of the toughest people I know can't sleep, have poor relationships, are trigged by certain things and it comes out in different ways and that, cumulatively is corrosive. Give yourself a decade waking up in a cold sweat every night, see how well you cope.

>>28160365
Meds will NOT have an irreversible effect on you unless you OD on them or take them during developmental periods of your life (except maybe something like xanax). If you decide a med doesn't work for you and you decide to stop it, especially after a 6 or so month period (enough time to learn how the med makes you feel after adjusting to it) you will not be scared, although you may suffer temporary withdrawals.
Meds are fine, just pay attention to how they make you feel and if it's an improvement or not. If your paranoia is strong and schizo like, make sure you look into anti-psychotics, even at a light dose. I have two housemates that besides either ADHD or OCD are mentally fine and they take an antipsychotic just go help them sleep, so the side effects can be manageable.

Just remember that anything you try can be quit without TOO much trouble. Extended withdrawal start to occur when you've been on meds for years but even they will pass.

That was a troll post. Based on your description, this is a pyramid scheme. Avoid these at all costs, and do not think of them as a job, because they are not.
Likely, they will not pay a regular wage or salary - you may receive a very small commission on sales (your boss/whoever is above you will likely make more off of your sales than you do)

The "company" will use what is basically mild brainwashing to convince you that the scheme is liberating and will make your financial and lifestyle dreams come true, and will never admit to being a pyramid scheme - may not even admit to being an MLM scheme.
The terms the "company" is using from your original post are common MLM terms that are not used in business elsewhere.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28159829

Judging from my own (different) experience with Lexapro, it probably won't. I think if it's doing that to you when you haven't been taking it that long, it's time to talk with your provider to see if another antidepressant/anti anxiety med would work better for you.

I was on it for about five years, at which point I decided to start tapering off of it, which took just over a year. I liked the Lexapro at first, I didn't experience apathy like that. It eventually set in and grew over time and towards the end of those first five years, I could tell that it was having that particular affect on me and I decided to stop taking it. Additionally, I had a vague, overarching feeling that I didn't need it anymore and I was having a harder and harder time creating complex sentences and using a greater vocabulary range (which I chalked up to "getting old" when I was in my mid-twenties). Within the first week of taking less of it, I had better access to my vocabulary banks and gradually have been getting better again at forming complex sentences.

posts.sub: Help a Canadian Pick a Degree
posts.com:
I’m a 1st year engineering student at Queen’s.

In about a month, I need to pick the engineering discipline I want to major in.

Should I pick computer engineering or mining engineering?

I know more about computer engineering but I think I’m equally interested in both.

I want to pick my degree based on earning potential, work-life balance, and possibility of relocation to the US.

Below are some observations I made (my observations could be wrong):

Prospects:
>In Canada, mining engineers earn more than computer (hardware and software) engineers.

>In Canada, there is greater demand for mining engineers.

>A computer engineer is more likely to get an American job than a mining engineer.

>A computer engineer working in the US will earn a LOT more than a Canadian mining engineer or really MOST other Canadian professionals.

>Canada is a very expensive country. Mining engineers can live in low cost of living areas.

>Computer engineers generally live in high cost of living areas unless they move out of Canada.

Work-Life Balance:
>Mining engineers either work on a rotational basis (2 weeks on 2 weeks off) or work 9-5 5 days a week.

>Computer engineers usually work 9-5 5 days a week but if sufficiently skilled can work remotely.

>Mining engineers rarely need to update their skills.

>Computer engineers, especially those working in software, need to constantly update their skills.

Housing:
>Mining engineers can afford homes in undesirable locations within Canada.

>Computer engineers cannot afford homes within Canada.

>Computer engineers can afford homes in desirable locations within the US if they are able to move to the US.

Skills:
>I started programming in my late teens so I am not an exceptional programmer. However, I am eager to improve.

>Idk much about mining but I feel that you’re not expected to know anything prior to starting mining engineering.

International Opportunities:
>CEs are more likely to get a TN or even H-1B visa and move to the US.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Those things are a meme for the gram. They work way worse than most other methods for making hot chocolate. They sound like a nice idea, the look like a nice idea, they are merely conspicuous consumption. My partner bought everybody these hot chocolate kits for christmas. They are basically chocolate chips, thickeners and flavourings in a baggie that you are supposed to stir into warm milk. They don't work for dick. You've either got to have so much hot milk that they are basically flavourless or there isn't enough thermal mass to melt it properly and a cup isn't big enough to correctly emulsify it all with anyway so you generally end up with a cup of lukewarm clots.

In case anybody wonders what the goat method is it is to use cornstarch. 2:2:1 cocoa, sugar and cornstarch made into a paste with a little milk and progressively thinned out (use a pan and stir or whisk) once it is at your desired consistency and on and off a gentle simmer melt into it as much chocolate as you want while gently controlling the heat. I'm usually using about three oz across two mugs. Some chocolate is sweet and I'll use more cocoa than cocoa to correct, some is more bitter and I'll use more sugar instead. Good additions/variations are a pinch of salt, cinnamon, some booze, a dash of cream, chilli powder, a little coffee, baking flavourings like salted caramel, peanut butter, hazelnut etc, framboise syrup, orange flavouring, peppermint candies, butterscotch candies. Top with marshmallows, decorate with sauces, extra cream, grated chocolate, sieved cocoa, stencil, whatever.

>>28155783
Get a remote job, become a digital nomad.
>How feasible is it to live in a place like Thailand for around 500 bucks a month or less?
>rent
Go on fazwaz, or dare I say Craigslist, and see what the prices are. The lowest you could conceivably go on rent is like $150 and that's gonna be outside Farang ghettos and in a non-centralized location. It probably doesn't include utilities either
>muh hostel!
You'd be lucky to find $5 dollars a night
>food
A single Thai dish with rice is like $1.5-3 dollars. Anything western is obviously more expensive. So if you wanted to keep your food budget low you'd have to eat Thai food pretty strictly; either from a hole in the wall restaurant or food cart
>misc
So let's say did that. You're left with $170. That's only about 5000 baht. Lowest monthly rate you could get for a motorbike rental is like 3000 baht = $3 dollars a day. Moto taxis are at least a dollar per trip, even on an app like bolt.
You'd also have to factor in the cost of an ED visa (IMO that's the best visa to stay for ~1 year).

So bottom line you could probably survive "comfortably" imo but that's about it. I don't think you'd find it particularly pleasant though. $1000/mo is a lot more ideal.

>>28101536

You have to look at any job application from the employers perspective. What is it that YOU can bring to THEM? How does hiring YOU benefit THEM? And here's the clincher, how does the benefits YOU bring stack up against or compete with ALL THE OTHER CANDIDATES?

Btw, "they get an employee" is not an answer to that question. So you need to start at the absolute bottom in a shithole dead end job where they need employee scale but face high turnover so basically everyone who applies gets hired. That's where you need to focus your applications. Build up some work experience over 18 months and you'll be in a much better position to get employed somewhere else.

Remember, a paper qualification is meaningless in 2023 without experience.

>>28159153
>It feels like life is pointless, and nothing I do matters.

Three main sources:
1) Brain chemicals/hormonal:
You need to regulate your body better - Eat proper meals, get in 30+ minutes of jogging a day, wake up and sleep at the same time every day, no phone 2 hours before bed. Drop caffeine or only have it in the mornings.
If those don't fix body chemical issues, could need medication but modern medicine for depression is like stone age tech. Don't recommend unless really serious, like gonna kill yourself serious.
2) Basic mental stimulation:
Everyone needs mental stimulation, the degree to which varies from person to person. Something that uniquely engages your attention and causes you to focus on the activity with no additional effort on your part. If it's a healthy activity, i.e. productive and valuable, then continue to nurture that interest. Examples are: Going to the gym, volunteering, gardening, cooking. If it's unhealthy, like it is for me, since my interest is videogames, you need to recognize what it is about the activity that causes that interest/focus and try to reorient it, which brings me to
3) Existential values:
Everyone has core beliefs and values. If you don't believe me, just think back to your childhood and really introspect on what dreams you had, or wanted to achieve. Maybe you wanted to be a doctor and help people, or maybe you had a shitty childhood and your dream was to not live in poverty with a family that beats you, whatever. You need to take some time and introspect about this and just write it down. Walk away, come back again tomorrow and write some
more. Keep mulling it over. (cont)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28159546
(cont)
For me, I never had any big dreams, but I just really enjoyed puzzles and the slow self improvement you could achieve in videogames. I reoriented my unhealthy core stimulating activities I enjoyed (2) toward loftier things like fascination with AI (3) to become a programmer. It gave me employment, which gave financial freedom (better access to good food, time for gym, healthcare, so "1"), while also giving me mental stimulation, and a existential goal to work toward.

I'm giving the cliffnotes since I'm phoneposting, but this is coming from someone who has/and is dealing with chronic depression for over a decade. I'm feeling pretty good these days (barring unrelated issues)
But yeah, keep a journal and just write out long form stream of consciousness writings on what you value in life and do some real soul searching in terms of what you really enjoy. It can literally be as superficial as "I just want to play videogames all day" or whatever. It just needs to be honest and allow you to reflect on who you are as a person.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28151312
She's shy and probably has doubts about herself and being good enough for you. She likely waited a month because she wasn't sure of herself or if she should contact you back. Do your best to make her feel comfortable around you. Getting a better image about yourself will do wonders for that.

I'm also a shy person and sometimes only check my phone every other day. She's moving, that would definitely contribute to her lack of responses. If I was moving, I would cancel most or all social plans until I was done. Long response times usually has to do with being busy with something else in that moment and not remember to text back on the first free moment, or not having heard the notification for your message, or having heard it but then getting distracted. If she's read your text, she might be too busy in that moment to think of a response. It's not like she's ignoring you entirely, she still responds the next day and is asking you out. She's interested.

>>28159700
My main concern with someone a bit younger would be that they're not 'stable' yet in terms of knowing what they actually want out of life/a relationship.
My last real relationship was with a 25yo when I was 28. He pursued me, he encouraged a fast pace, talked about moving in, having kids, etc, not to a point that was too fast or clingy but just in a way that made it seem like he really knew what he wanted and was bold enough to go for it. Then when it came to the crunch he noped out hard into a quarter life crisis and dumped me lol. Same thing happened to a couple of my friends dating a guy in the mid-20s range (though with less/no age gap), so from where I'm standing it seems like guys that age are just prone to a crisis.
That doesn't make them undatable by any means, I'm sure plenty get through fine, but I'd imagine that's a concern you're liable to run into, especially with older women who might have already experienced it.

posts.sub: Grieving and confused over estranged father, can anyone relate?
posts.com: My father passed away today. We hadn't spoken in more than 6 years, and only twice in the last 13. He and my mom had me at a young age, too young, and gave up everything to take care of me. He was abused as a child by his father, who comes from similar stock, and was troubled since he was a kid, getting involved with drugs, and alcohol, and violence to get his way. He tried to do better, in his own way. I can recall a few brief moments where we did something resembling bonding. We especially bonded over computers and video games, as it was his wheelhouse. His favorite game to play with me was Team Fortress 2, but he introduced me to all kinds of games that I still love to this day. His taste in music also rubbed off on me; he was especially partial to Nirvana and Alice in Chains, and grunge in general. He went to work to take care of me, and though he was never a percect man, and often times not even a good man, I could tell he cared in his own messed-up way. He would try to "toughen me up", which, when he was drunk, meant daring me to hit him as hard as I could. Sometimes when I had an issue with my PC, he wouldn't help me, but then explained that he was trying to show me how to solve my own problems. Like I said, he didn't have good context for how to be a father, and was mentally ill on top of everything. At a point he suffered a severe back injury, and got addicted to prescription painkillers. They took him off of them after awhile, yet did nothing to curb his addiction, and so fell victim to it, and started spiraling downwards. One day, he was drunk and high, and we got into a fight. Fists were exchanged, and that was the very last abuse I put up with. I tried so hard for so long to hold out hope, to help him; as a young boy I had to talk him down from committing suicide more than once. P/1

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28159242
He was troubled. He was an asshole. He was abusive. He was an addict. But he was my dad, and in the last year of his life, due to medical necessity, he had finally kicked alcohol. I planned to, upon knowing for sure that he really had done it this time, to reach back out and at least tell him all the things that were on my mind. I wanted to tell him that what he did to us was wrong, I wanted him to understand how it has effected us and will always effect us, I wanted to get a sincere apology from him, I wanted to forgive him. I just wanted him to see that it didn't have to be like that. It never did. I hated him for so long for choosing drugs and booze over us, until I grew to appreciate the things he struggled with more, and knew what addiction could be like. I wanted us to talk about games again, and internet memes that I'm sure he was into. I wanted to have something with him if I could. In spite of all the pain, all the anxiety, the PTSD we all suffered from him, he was still my dad once upon a time. I loved him. Now there's no chance to say anything anymore. It's over, and because I was too stubborn to speak to him even though he had tried to reach out over the years, I'll never get to tell him any of this. The regret stings so fucking bad. Why did I have to keep him out for so long? Why couldn't I just face him and at least yell at him or tell him what an asshole he had been? Why could you I just say something?

If you bothered to read this thank you bros. If you can relate please tell me how you dealt with this, I'm so mixed up and in pain right now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28159245

He isn't really gone while you're around, you can speak to him because he exists within you. Once you die, then he will truly be gone.
I think in moments of clarity all troubled men with any degree of reflection, including you and your father, come to see that we are in a piece of shit world that brings out the worst in all us, even though we try to do better. The idealized form of him, the best him that he could be, can only exist in your eye, and you're doing a good thing by understanding and humanizing him as a fellow gamer and as someone else's wandering son.
He isn't pissed off at you, I mean, would you be? Considering we're all a bunch of dudes being incomprehensibly thrown around by life, it's hard to really be pissed off at any fellow clueless particle who bumps into you as you're all being knocked around. From an afterlife vantage point.

We're a bunch if clueless retards getting beaten up by an incomprehensible world until we die from it. How mad can you even be at a fellow retard?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28159245
So sorry anon. I'm probably your dad's age if not a little younger or older. I've lost a few friends to pain pills and misc drugs these past few years. I wanted to talk to their kids, but although they are full grown adults with thoughts and feelings like yours now and the last I saw of them was when they were embryos in their mothers bellies. I lost contact with those friends when we were young. I guess I kinda wanted to know what happened. I guess you kinda told me.

Our parents were super successful. Much of the meaningful economy was locked off from us and wages to products experienced a huge gap.

I tell myself that we all wanted to escape reality from how hard things became. We all did it in our own way. It's not to make an excuse for your father. Clearly he could have escaped without hard drugs, but they were prescribing serious pain meds in the 2000s. No other generation before us got so addicted after injuries. After seeing my friends I straight up didn't trust doctors nor drugs.

That said, you have to poke around and find a way to be productive without drugs and alcohol. I'm sure your dad was sorry for the things he did. I'm sure he was lonely w/o you in life, but if you forgive him, I'm sure you will be reacquainted with him. Unfortunately, in this plane, he is now in the rearview mirror and now you have to look forward.

Pray to God for guidance and ask for help looking forward and making a future for yourself. Good luck and may God be with you anon. I'm sorry for your loss.

You're doing it wrong.

I got fired for slacking too much but really enjoyed that few months. It was after working a dishwasher job for a week before quitting. I got to sit in front of a computer drink a coffee, and read a selection of WorkSafe news sites for news articles and entertainment. When a boss was looking over my shoulder I was on a work tab and all other times I was on a news tab and would tab back in when a call came in from the autodialer.
Remote job has a different dynamic where everything is blocked on the work computer, but they cannot see me, so I just use a mobile phone, tablet, post on 4chan during my shift watch videos if it's really slow or play a few phone games.

venting-
From fourth grade on through senior year I loved the same girl. Loved her. We were in band together, our parents were friends, and we were together all the time. I never, ever had the nerve to ask her out then Sophomore year she asked me to the Sadie Hawkins and I was pumped. She asked me! We had a great time so I immediately asked her to the Winter Formal dance. She was so gorgeous.
But she wore heels. She was technically taller than me anyway (I am 5'7", she's almost 5'8") but with heels she towered over me. lots of people were sniggering at us. When i went to get drinks guys offered to get me a step stool to reach the table.
I was so humiliated I didn't talk to her for weeks. I was sure she was humiliated, too. Only really talked to her 1 time before we graduated.
I very carefully never looked her up on social media. I moved far away for school and got my PhD, now I work as a therapist.
The owner of the practice is, like me, 5'7" tall and, like me, he was balding in HS, totally bald by 25. He's older.
His wife is 5'10" and they have 7 kids. They are very happy. It just ate at me, he never cared she was taller. I realized my insecurities were what killed what could have been wonderful.
So I looked her up.
Never, ever look up the one that got away.
And don't let insecurities break you

>>28156710
Consider this: a counterbalance forklift seven days training course plus the exam to obtain the license costs about, what? Maybe 800 quid, if that. That's less than 10 hours of overtime in a week, spread throughout 8 weeks, which is a little less than two months. One could do it in 4 weeks if they are grafters, hard workers, and can work 60 hours weeks. And mind you, that license will be valid in many workplaces. A company's internal license is only valid inside that one particular workplace and not elsewhere, even if one is assessed by the exact same people and organization.
But in order to get that training from a company, one would have to spend at the very least six months while having excellent work ethics, while having a contract, which is something not everyone has the opportunity of getting. And it would also required being picked for it and there is no guarantee for that.

That was just an example. My point is: have good work ethics, work overtime, save up that money, invest your money on yourselves, get an easier job that pays better and repeat the process.
I'll say something else too: if you have a low tier job always, _ALWAYS_ look for something better. Start seeing shit jobs as nothing more than stepping stones and a way of not being unemployed.
Even a manager of operations from one such low tier workplace EXPLICITLY told me not to settle for what I was doing back then, but to be on the constant lookout for opportunities and not to show any loyalty to any such workplaces. Let that fucking sink in: one of the place's big bosses told me that of all the people.

posts.com:
I was fired today. I was very good at the technical part of my job, but my boss kept a list of every administrative misstep or lax behavior on my part all year and terminated me without warning the minute she found someone to replace my work.
What gets me is I barely ever interacted with her, I maybe spoke to her three times this past year. She had delegated supervising to someone else. I think she just wanted to get ride of me the minute I was put under her for God knows what reason.

I'm feeling nauseous and unable to sleep over stress. It took me almost a year of applying to get a single interview that led to this job. I have lots of money saved that I can continue to pay rent for several months, but I do not want to blow my savings on bumming nor can I face the shame of going back to parents.
Going through the application process again sounds slightly better with years of experience now, but I will inevitably have to explain why I am unemployed now and I don't think "my boss was a bitch" will pass any muster. Any upstanding place will require me to say I was fired and that isn't going to do me any favors.
And I'm mostly sickened by thinking about work right now, having to go to the same sort of corporate people from a position of need. I'm not against working for a living, but I'm against these petty social games that have nothing to do with actually getting work done. Having to do all that with an albatross on my record is stressing me to hell.
All day I was treated like a pariah, giving me strong advance warning of bad news (I was expecting a cordial dismissal based on an expiring term of my employment that they opted not to renew, not an actual disciplinary termination based on little stuff from months ago). No greetings or talk, not even a nod in the hallway. It was most noticeable when someone in a meeting who apparently didn't get the memo and kept referring to me on certain topics and everyone else made a point of never addressing any part involving me.

>>28159096
When you "Delete" data from a computer it doesn't actually do anything other than free up a pointer to a memory address. The data still exists at whatever the memory address is until it's overwritten. There is software you can download to search through the actual bytes on your hard drive to find whatever data you're looking for. I've never personally done it though.

It sounds like possibly there's a physical problem with your hard drive, which happens sometimes. You probably need a new hard drive.
